title: Import Python Project Tutorial with UV
text:
This document provides detailed instructions for setting up your Python environment for this course/workshop. You should have already read the information in the 00_setup_slides and completed the installation of Visual Studio Code and Python using uv by following Setup Notebook 01.







This method is recommended for newer programmers not yet familiar with git and Github and for any user who only needs a static copy of the repository.

open the chosen GitHub repository. In this tutorial, we will import the repository for Dartmouth Libraries‚Äô Python Essential Workshop Series.
Click the green ‚ÄúCode‚Äù button on the repository page
Select ‚ÄúDownload ZIP‚Äù
Extract the ZIP file to a memorable location (e.g., ~/Documents/Python-Courses/)
Important: To get updates, you‚Äôll need to re-download




This method is recommended for users familiar with git and Github, have git installed, have a Github account, and who wish to create a dynamic copy (‚Äúclone‚Äù) of the repository. A clone allows you to update your local repo when its online counterpart as been updated (using the pull command in git). It also allows you to push any changes you made locally back up to the remote repository, but only if the repository administrator has given you these privileges.
If you have Git installed:
# before cloning, move the current working directory to the folder where you want to clone this project
git clone [REPOSITORY-URL]
# for example:
# git clone git@github.com:Dartmouth-Libraries/py-essentials_ws.git
To update the local version of the repository after the online version has been updated:
git pull origin main






cd path/to/[repository-name]





You can tell if a repository is set up for uv if it has a uv.lock file in its root folder.
Run the following in the terminal:
# This creates a .venv directory and installs all packages
uv sync
This command:

Creates a virtual environment in .venv/
Installs Python if the correct version isn‚Äôt available
Installs all packages specified in pyproject.toml
Creates/updates uv.lock for reproducibility




Prior to uv, Python project dependencies were usually stored in a requirements.txt file. To install all dependencies from this file and convert the project to a uv project, run the following in the terminal:

First, initiate uv for this project:

uv sync



uv add -r requirements.txt
If this doesn‚Äôt provide desired results, review the documentation on this process in the uv guide.







Note: This may take 5-10 minutes on first run.
# Run the setup verification script
uv run python scripts/00_setup.py







Launch VS Code
File ‚Üí Open Folder
Select the course repository folder





Open Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P on Windows/Linux, Cmd+Shift+P on macOS)
Type ‚ÄúPython: Select Interpreter‚Äù
Choose the interpreter from .venv (it should show up as ./venv/bin/python or similar)

If the .venv interpreter doesn‚Äôt appear:

Click ‚ÄúEnter interpreter path‚Ä¶‚Äù
Navigate to: .venv/Scripts/python.exe (Windows) or .venv/bin/python (Mac/Linux)




When you open a .ipynb file:

VS Code will prompt you to select a kernel
Choose the same .venv Python interpreter





Open scripts/00_setup.py
You should see the Python version in the bottom-right status bar
Right-click in the editor ‚Üí ‚ÄúRun Python File in Terminal‚Äù







# Activate environment and run verification script
uv run python scripts/00_setup.py



You can also test manually:
# Check Python version
uv run python --version

# Test package imports
uv run python -c "import pandas; import numpy; import matplotlib; print('All packages loaded successfully!')"

# List installed packages
uv pip list






Solution: The installation directory isn‚Äôt in your PATH.
Windows:
Add %USERPROFILE%\.cargo\bin to your PATH environment variable.
macOS/Linux:
Add this to your ~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc, or equivalent:
export PATH="$HOME/.cargo/bin:$PATH"
Then run: source ~/.bashrc (or ~/.zshrc)



Solution: uv can install Python for you:
uv python install 3.11
uv sync



Solution 1: Ensure you have build tools installed
Windows:

Install Visual Studio Build Tools

macOS:
xcode-select --install
Linux (Ubuntu/Debian):
sudo apt-get install build-essential python3-dev
Solution 2: Try installing pre-built wheels:
uv pip install --only-binary :all: [package-name]



Solution:

Make sure .venv folder exists in your project root
Reload VS Code (Ctrl+Shift+P ‚Üí ‚ÄúDeveloper: Reload Window‚Äù)
Manually browse to the interpreter:

-   Windows: `.venv\Scripts\python.exe`

-   Mac/Linux: `.venv/bin/python`



Solution:

Ensure Jupyter extension is installed
Install ipykernel in your environment:

uv pip install ipykernel

Select the .venv kernel when opening a notebook
Restart VS Code if needed




Solution:

Ensure you‚Äôve selected the correct Python interpreter
Check that python.analysis.extraPaths includes your project root
Reload VS Code window




Solution:

Don‚Äôt use sudo with uv commands
Ensure you have write permissions to the project directory
On Windows, run terminal as regular user (not administrator)




Possible causes:

First run always takes longer
Slow internet connection
Antivirus scanning

Solutions:

Be patient on first run
Disable antivirus temporarily for .venv folder
Use uv sync --offline if you‚Äôve run it before








Keep all work within this project folder
Use relative paths (or pathlib)
Save scripts with descriptive names: verb_noun.py (e.g., analyze_sales.py)




Good:

clean_data.py
2024_01_15_sales_report.csv
figure_01_scatterplot.png

Bad:

script1.py
final FINAL (2) copy.py
sales data.csv (spaces can be problematic)




In Terminal:
# Always use uv run to ensure correct environment
uv run python scripts

title: Python Setup
text:
This document provides detailed instructions for installing and setting up Visual Studio Code and Python (via uv)






Go to https://code.visualstudio.com/
Download for your operating system (it auto-detects)
Install VS Code with default options
Launch VS Code

Once opened, let‚Äôs install essential extensions (click Extensions icon - looks like four squares - in sidebar or press Ctrl+Shift+X):

Search for ‚ÄòPython‚Äô - install the one by Microsoft
Search for ‚ÄòJupyter‚Äô - install the one by Microsoft
Search for ‚ÄòQuarto‚Äô - use to create and work with Quarto notebooks and presentations
Search for ‚ÄòGit History‚Äô (optional but useful)

These extensions will help VS Code work with Python.



Now we install uv, which will handle EVERYTHING else for us - including Python itself. This is the modern way to manage Python projects. uv is a fast Python package and project manager that we‚Äôll use for managing dependencies.
Dependencies are other software that are needed for a program to run. For Python, this often means
Open the integrated terminal in VS Code:

Windows/Linux: Press Ctrl + `` (that‚Äôs the backtick key, usually above Tab)
Mac: Press Cmd + ``

Or use the menu: Terminal ‚Üí New Terminal


Windows: Type in a Powershell terminal
powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"
If you get an error like this - Error: Powershell requires an execution policy... - then we need to temporarily bypass Powershell‚Äôs policies by running:
powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"


If the above did not work you can also try:
winget option 1. install winget 2. Run in the terminal from VSC:
winget install --id=astral-sh.uv -e
scoop option 1. install scoop 2. Run in the terminal from VSC:
scoop install uv
Troubleshooting Windows: If uv is not recognized:
 Check if %USERPROFILE%\.local\bin is in your PATH
 Add manually: System Properties ‚Üí Environment Variables ‚Üí Path ‚Üí Add the directory
 Restart your terminal




Type the following in a Mac/Linux terminal:
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh


If the above did not work on your Mac you can also try:
homebrew option



# If using the shell script, add to your shell profile
# For zsh (default on modern macOS):
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc

# For bash:
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

# Verify
uv --version




# Shell script (works on most distributions)
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

# Add to PATH (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"

# Reload shell
source ~/.bashrc  # or source ~/.zshrc

# Verify
uv --version
Troubleshooting Linux:
If curl is not installed: sudo apt install curl (Ubuntu/Debian)
Permission denied: The script installs to ~/.local/bin, which shouldn't require sudo



After installation completes:

Close the terminal tab in VS Code (click the trash can icon)
Open a new terminal (Ctrl/Cmd + ` again)
Verify installation by running the following (Mac/Linux or if Windows in Command Prompt or Git Bash):

uv --version
You should see something like uv 0.4.x or higher.
Troubleshooting time: Common issues

‚ÄúIf ‚Äòuv‚Äô is not recognized: The installation script may need admin rights, or you may need to restart VS Code‚Äù
‚ÄúMac users: If you get a security warning, go to System Preferences ‚Üí Security & Privacy ‚Üí Allow‚Äù





With uv we don‚Äôt need to install Python separately. When we create our first project, uv will automatically install the right Python version for us. But let‚Äôs verify uv can find or install Python:
Enter the following in the terminal (Mac/Linux or if Windows in Command Prompt or Git Bash):
uv python list
This shows all Python versions uv knows about. Don‚Äôt worry if it‚Äôs empty - uv will download Python when we need it.
We can install the latest version of Python with:
uv python install
This downloads and installs the latest stable version of Python, managed by uv. No PATH configuration needed, no installers to run, no clicking through installation wizards.
Or we can specify an older version to install:
Enter the following in the terminal (Mac/Linux or if Windows in Command Prompt or Git Bash):
uv python install 3.12
Verify:
Enter the following in the terminal (Mac/Linux or if Windows in Command Prompt or Git Bash):
uv python list




No need to go to python.org, download an installer
don‚Äôt need to worry about ‚ÄúAdd to PATH‚Äù (a common error in Python installation, when a Python IDE like VSC cannot find Python or cannot find the version of Python you want to use)
don‚Äôt need to worry about conflicting with other Python installations

title: Python Setup

Python Setup Slides
Tutorial 1: Python Installation & Setup
Tutorial 2: Create Python Project from Scratch
Tutorial 3: Import Existing Python Project

title: Python Setup
text:
1. Overview
This repository contains tutorials to walk you through installing Python and getting started with your first Python project on your own computer.
There are many ways to install and run Python. Here, we provide instructions for our recommended set up for new Python users that involves:

installing and using the coding editor and IDE (Integrated Development Environment) software Visual Studio Code
installing and using uv to assist in the installation of Python and the creation of reproducible and transportable coding projects (using something called ‚Äúvirtual environments‚Äù).
following computational and coding best practices to set up a Python project.

title: Python Setup
text:
2. Author
Jeremy Mikecz, Research Facilitation, Dartmouth Libraries January 2026

title: Python Setup
text:
3. Designed for:

in-person / virtual instruction
or asynchronous, self-paced learning

‚Ä¶for Python beginners and those who have used Python before and want to learn how to best set it up on their own computer.

title: Python Setup
text:
4. Learning Objectives
Upon completing the lessons offered here, the student will be able to:

install and run Python on their local computer, whether it be a Mac, PC, or Linux
set up a new Python project in Visual Studio Code from scratch following programming and computational best practices.
import an existing Python project and modify it within VSC.
write their first markdown file (README.md)
write and run their first Python script and Python Jupyter notebook.

7. Getting Started
To complete the set up tutorial, open the setup/ folder and do the following in order:

Review the 00_setup_slides presentation (optional, but provides from useful background)
Complete the Python Setup Tutorial (Notebook 01 in setup/ folder)
Complete the Create a New Python Project from Scratch Tutorial (Notebook 02 in setup/ folder)
Complete the Python Setup Tutorial (Notebook 03 in setup/ folder)

Strong community support
Free and open source
Cross-platform
Used across disciplines: from digital humanities to computational biology

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Typical Python Setup

Install Python
install an IDE (Integrated Development Environment): software that combines tools for writing, editing, compiling, and debugging code.
Install Python packages to ‚Äúglobal‚Äù environment on your computer

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Resulting Problems

IDE can‚Äôt find Python (‚ÄòPython is not recognized as a command‚Äô errors?)
Code that worked on one computer but broke on another? (dependency conflicts)
updating one project causes another not to work
installing the wrong package causes your Python installation to break
Multiple Python versions fighting each other?
your project code works differently on different computers (making collaboration difficult)

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Common error messages:

'python' is not recognized as an internal or external command
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pandas'
Python version mismatch
Permission denied

title: Python Setup Workshop
section: Recommended Python Set Up Approach: UV + VSC
text:
Recommended Python Set Up Approach: UV + VSC

uv: A new, fast tool that manages everything‚ÄîPython versions,virtual environments, and packages‚Äîall in one place.
Visual Studio Code: A modern editor that works seamlessly with uv and Python.
Project best practices: folder/file organization; file-naming; virtual environment for each project; rigorous documentation

We‚Äôre building good habits from day one, not adding them later.

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Project Organization
One folder ‚Äì one project

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Project Organization
Folder Organization:
my-research-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ data/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/              # Original, untouched data
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ processed/        # Cleaned, transformed data
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ code                  # this may include Python scripts (.py) and coding notebooks
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ results/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ figures/          # Plots and visualizations
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tables/           # Output tables/statistics
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/                 # Documentation, notes
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore           # Tell git what NOT to track
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md            # Project description and instructions
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ pyproject.toml       # Python dependencies (with uv)

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Project Organization
Why this structure?
+ Separation of concerns: Raw data stays pristine, processed data is separate

+ Findability: Six months from now, you'll know where everything is
+ Collaboration: Others can navigate your project easily

+ Scalability: Works for small and large projects
Key principles:
+ Keep raw data in data/raw/ and NEVER modify it directly
+ All data processing should be scripted and reproducible
+ Results should be generated by code, not manually created
+ One project = one self-contained folder"

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
File Naming Conventions
Some common conventions:

Lowercase with underscores: my-script.py or my_script.py
Be descriptive: Names should tell you what the file contains or does
NO SPACES: For file names, you should replace whitespace with hyphens or underscores instead. Spaces cause issues in terminals. For Python code and folders containing Python code, it is recommended to avoid hyphens too as Python has difficulty importing code from folders or files with hyphens or any special characters besides underscores. Using hyphens for data files is perfectly fine.
Avoid special characters with exception of underscore _ whenever possible.
Use number prefixes for sequences: 01_, 02_, 03_ keeps scripts in order
Include dates if relevant: YYYY_MM_DD or YYYYMMDD to format sorts chronologically (you may also use hyphens, i.e.¬†YYYY-MM-DD for data files and other files or folders that DO NOT contain Python code).
Consistent within a project: Pick a style and stick with it

For general file management naming conventions see Harvard‚Äôs guide to file naming.
For Python specific naming conventions (for files and folders, but also for the names of variables, functions, classes, etc. see The Pep 8 Style Guide.

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Documentation
Most important document: README.md file. This is where users go to first to learn more about a project.
What goes in a README:

project title & overview
how to set up / get started
how to use
data description
description of other content
how to cite
license information

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Dependency Conflicts
Problem

Project A (from 2022) needs pandas version 1.3
Project B (new project) needs pandas version 2.0

If you just install your Python dependencies to a global environment (meaning they can be accessed anywhere on your personal computer) then your Python setup can only work for one of these packages. For example, if you try to run Project A, but you have pandas 2.0 installed on your computer, then you may receive a dependency conflict error.

title: Python Setup Workshop
text:
Solution: Virtual Environments
A virtual environment is like a separate, isolated workspace for each Python project on your computer.
A virtual environment keeps each project‚Äôs packages separate and organized, preventing conflicts and making your code easy to share
Think of it as:

A project-specific toolbox that contains only the tools (packages) you need for that project
A separate room for each project, so things don‚Äôt get mixed up
A backpack you pack differently for each trip/project

Value of Virtual Environments

avoid conflicts
keep things clean
easy sharing
protect your system

Visual
WITHOUT Virtual Environments:

title: Create Python Project from Scratch
text:
This document provides detailed instructions for setting up your Python environment for this course/workshop. You should have already read the information in the 00_setup_slides and completed the installation of Visual Studio Code and Python using uv by following Setup Notebook 01.



setup project in Visual Studio Code (10 mins.)
write your first markdown document (10)
set up virtual environment
write your first script
write your first notebook
import external data







Create a new folder for your sample project in a place which you can easily find again. Follow recommended file naming projects (outlined in 00_setup_slides) such as using underscores _ in place of whitespace, avoiding special characters, etc. i.e.:
~/Users/your-user-name/Documents/python_code/sample_project




Visual Studio Code and other IDEs allow you to load an entire project at once. Thus, you can easily switch between projects and when you return to a given project all the same files that were open before are opened once again. Below, we will open our sample project folder and modify it.

Open Visual Studio Code, which you installed with notebook 01.
Click on File ‚Äì> Open Folder. Navigate to your new project folder and open it.
In the left pane of VSC, click on the Explorer icon (looks like pages or files) and you will see your empty folder there.

Add the following folders using the **+ Folder icon **:

|--code
|--data
|--docs
|--results





As noted in the opening slides presentation (html or pdf) ‚ÄúA virtual environment keeps each project‚Äôs packages separate and organized, preventing conflicts and making your code easy to share.‚Äù
We will now use uv to create a virtual environment for our sample project.



Select the Terminal tab at the top of VSC ‚Äì> New Terminal
A new terminal should appear at the bottom.
If you are using a PC, it is recommended you use a Command Prompt terminal instead of Powershell. To open Command, select the + symbol at the far right side of the terminal pane, and select Command Prompt.





In the terminal, you can test to see if VSC can find your Python and uv installations (just as we did in notebook 01) by running the following code:

uv --version
uv python list



Make sure you are in the project root folder, i.e.¬†your terminal should look like something like this (with a path to your project directory shown):

If you are not in the project root directory you can navigate to it by using the cd (change directory) command. Some tips:

to navigate up one directory type cd ..
to navigate up 3 directories type cd ../../..
to navigate from the current working directory into your code folder type cd code.
to navigate down two directories, type something like this: cd code/scripts (assuming the code folder is in your current working directory and a scripts folder is inside of that.

Now, run the following in your project‚Äôs root directory from the terminal:
# This initiaties a new uv environment for your project
uv init
You will see in the Explorer pane on the left side of VSC several new files and folders were created in your project‚Äôs working directory. The above command:

Installed Python if the correct version isn‚Äôt available
Created a pyproject.toml file, where uv will store information about the packages / dependencies used in this project.
Created a .python-version file to store the version of Python used for this project.




Initiating uv may also create a uv.lock file and a '.venv folder if you have already installed some packages. Let‚Äôs test this out by installing a package to our local environment at which point this file and folder will be created:
Run in the terminal:
uv add requests
Certainly, now you should see the following in your project‚Äôs root directory:
-   a `uv.lock` file which may be used by others (or by yourself in a different environment) to reproduce the exact same computing environment for your project.

-   a `.venv` folder where the code for all projects added to the local environment are stored
You can also install / add multiple packages at once:
uv add numpy pandas rich
You can use uv remove to uninstall packages. We really didn‚Äôt need requests. Let‚Äôs uninstall it:
uv remove requests
You can review what packages have been installed in multiple ways. You can open either the pyproject.toml or the uv.lock file. Or you can run the following in the terminal:
uv pip list
You should see something like this:
Package         Version
--------------- -----------
markdown-it-py  4.0.0
mdurl           0.1.2
numpy           2.4.1
pandas          2.3.3
pygments        2.19.2
python-dateutil 2.9.0.post0
pytz            2025.2
rich            14.2.0
six             1.17.0
tzdata          2025.3
*Note: the .toml file and uv pip list return all packages installed including dependencies. For example, when we installed rich, UV also installed the packages rich depends on: markdown-it-py, mdurl, and pygments. In contrast, the uv.lock just lists the actual packages that you, the user, installed:
dependencies = [
    "numpy>=2.4.1",
    "pandas>=2.3.3",
    "rich>=14.2.0",
]
This is because uv.lock serves as instructions for the re-creation of this environment on another computer. If you were to open this project on a different computer, you would run the command uv sync, which would recreate your environment by installing the specific versions of numpy, pandas, and rich you have installed on your machine. When those are installed, their dependencies will be automatically installed as well.
Now, try running this:
pip list
Notice any difference from the results returned by uv pip list? In my case this second command returned many, many more packages? Why? It‚Äôs because the uv command automatically just retrieves the names of packages installed to the local virtual environment, whereas pip is retrieving all packages installed. That is why, under the pip system, you need to activate your virtual environment with .venv/Scripts/activate (Windows) or .venv/bin/activate (Macs) every time you open a project. Fortunately, with uv, we are automatically using the virtual environment whenever we call uv within a project that has one.



One final step: every time we start a new project in VSC we need to configure VSC to use the correct version of Python. We can do this by selecting our Python interpreter:

Open the ‚ÄúShow and Run Command Bars‚Äù (either select from central dropdown project menu at top of screen or by clicking CTRL + SHIFT + P on Windows or CMD + CTRL + SPACE on a Mac)
Search for and select Python: Select Interpreter



Select ‚ÄúPython: Select Interpreter‚Äù from Show and Run Command Bars


Choose the version of Python installed to your local environment. It should look something like this: `Python 3.14.2 (name-of-project) .venv/Scripts/python.exe Recommended‚Äù



Select the version of Python found within your local project environment



Let‚Äôs view which version of Python is being used by this project. Run the following in the terminal:
uv run python --version




 ‚úÖ Install VS Code
 ‚úÖ Install Python extension (ms-python.python)
 ‚úÖ Install Jupyter extension
 ‚úÖ Open project folder
 ‚úÖ Select interpreter: Ctrl+Shift+P ‚Üí "Python: Select Interpreter" ‚Üí .venv
 ‚úÖ Configure terminal to use uv



A markdown file is a text file that allows you to use simple symbols to specify its formatting. This notebook and the 00_setup_slides presentation were both created using markdown.
Some commonly used symbols:
# Header level 1 (note '#' should be the first symbol on the line and followed by a single whitespace)
## Header level 2
### Header level 3
**bold**
*italics*
[filename](link/to/file)   # to create hyperlinks
```
place code blocks between sets of 3 back ticks
```
In the Explorer pane on the left, create a new file using the + File icon and name it README.md (.md is the extension for a markdown file).
Create a skeletal outline of a README file using headers of different levels, bold, italics, links, and code blocks (see the symbol directory above or the Markdown Guide‚Äôs Cheat Sheet for more examples of Markdown syntax). Include the following information:

tentative name of your project
name(s) of author(s) (you!)
Overview section
Data section
Methods section

Save the file.




Create a Python script in your code/ folder and name it something like this: greeting.py.

Create a new script either by navigating to the code/ folder, right-clicking it, and selecting New File. Be sure to give the file the .py extension.
OR File ‚Äì> New File and then give your file a name and place it in the code folder.
*Note: using the correct extension is essential so the computer knows how to read it. A .py file is a plain text file containing Python code that can be run with software like VSC or from the command line.*

Type / paste in the following code (modifying it to make it your own) in the Python script:

# Get the user's name
name = input("What's your name? ")

# print(name, "is a beautiful name.")

Save the script (important: when you run a script it will only run the most recently saved version).
Run your script in the terminal using uv:

uv run code/greeting.py

Other options to run this file:

Right-click anywhere within greeting.py (in VSC) and select Run Python ‚Äì> Run Python File in Terminal
You can also run the script by selecting the Play icon button at the top of the editor window where you have greeting.py. Note: with this method, you are NOT using uv to run the script. Therefore, VSC may not know which Python version on your computer to run or it may choose a version that doesn‚Äôt work. If you get an error: choose the version that looks something like this: Python 3.XX.X (sample-project) .\.venv\Scripts\python.exe              Workspace.




add to your Python script:
# Get their favorite color
color = input("What's your favorite color? ")

# Respond based on their color choice
if color.lower() == "blue":
    print(f"Hello, {name}! Blue is a calm and peaceful color. Great choice!")
elif color.lower() == "red":
    print(f"Hello, {name}! Red is bold and energetic. I like it!")
elif color.lower() == "green":
    print(f"Hello, {name}! Green is the color of nature. Very refreshing!")
else:
    print(f"Hello, {name}! {color.title()} is a wonderful color!")



You can only do a few simple things with core Python code. Anything more complex - from data analysis to statistics, working with images and text, etc. - you will need to:

install the package to your local environment using uv (do this once per project)
import the package into any scripts or notebooks that use it (must include in each code script or notebook)

We will create a random compliments generator in a Python script, which requires the use of two packages:

random (which is part of the core Python installation and thus DOES NOT need to be installed, but DOES need to be imported) and
rich (which DOES NEED to be installed AND imported).

To install rich run the following in the terminal:
uv add rich 
You can confirm the installation of this package to your local environment in multiple ways.

Open the pyproject.toml file and you should see it listed among the dependencies.
Open uv.lock and you can see information about the installed rich package.
Review code files for the rich package stored in .venv/Lib/site-packages.
Type uv pip list or uv pip freeze in the command line / terminal.

NOTE: Never manually modify any of the above unless you know what you are doing. These files and folders are manually updated by uv when you run uv commands.
Then paste / type the following into a new Python script called compliment_generator.py.
import random
from rich import print

# List of compliments
compliments = [
    "You're doing an amazing job learning Python! üéâ",  # \U0001F389
    "Your curiosity is inspiring! üåü",                  # \U00002B50
    "You have great potential as a programmer! üíª",
    "Keep up the excellent work! üöÄ",                   # \U0001F680"
    "You're braver than you think for trying something new! üí™"
    "‚ú®"
]

# Get user's name
name = input("What's your name? ")

# Pick a random compliment
chosen_compliment = random.choice(compliments)

# Print with color using rich
print(f"\n[bold cyan]Hey {name}![/bold cyan]")
print(f"[green]{chosen_compliment}[/green]\n")
Note: to acquire these and other emojis:

on a PC press Windows + . or Windows + ;
On a Mac type Command + Control + Space.
On a Linux type Ctrl + . or Ctrl + ;.

Try running this script from the command line using the same procedure introduced in the previous step.




Coding notebooks allow a user to create a more interactive, modular code script. These notebooks allow users to mix markdown texts (with human-readable instructions and explanations) with code cells, which can be run one at a time or all at once. They also allow users to view various intermediary results (i.e.¬†data tables or visualizations) right within their notebook.
Jupyter is the most commonly used type of coding notebook for Python.



To use Jupyter first we need to install it using uv. Run the following in the terminal:

uv add jupyter




Right-click in the Explorer sidebar (where your files are)
Click ‚ÄúNew File‚Äù
Name it: my_first_notebook.ipynb

-   The `.ipynb` extension is important!

Press Enter





When the notebook opens, look at the top-right corner
Click ‚ÄúSelect Kernel‚Äù
Choose ‚ÄúPython Environments‚Ä¶‚Äù
Select the one that says .venv or uv





Click in the first cell
Type some Python code
Press Shift + Enter to run the cell
That‚Äôs it! üéâ




A short cheatsheet for working with Jupyter notebooks (or click here for a more extensive cheatsheet:
‚ïî‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïó
‚ïë      JUPYTER NOTEBOOK SHORTCUTS              ‚ïë
‚ï†‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ï£

‚ïë                                              ‚ïë

‚ïö‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïù
Copy and paste these cells into your notebook to practice:


Click the cell, then change it to ‚ÄúMarkdown‚Äù using the dropdown at the top
# üéâ My First Jupyter Notebook

Welcome to my coding adventure! Today I'm learning about Jupyter notebooks.

## What I'll practice:
- Running Python code in cells
- Using **markdown** for notes
- Making calculations
- Creating simple visualizations
---

**Date:** January 2025  
**Mood:** Excited! üöÄ




# Let's do some calculations!
print("üßÆ Quick Math Practice")
print("-" * 30)

my_age = 25  # Change this to your age!
python_age = 2025 - 1991  # Python was created in 1991

print(f"I am {my_age} years old")
print(f"Python is {python_age} years old")
print(f"Python is {python_age - my_age} years older than me!")

üßÆ Quick Math Practice
------------------------------
I am 25 years old
Python is 34 years old
Python is 9 years older than me!





## üí≠ My Observations

The cool thing about notebooks is that I can:
1. Write code
2. See the results immediately
3. Add notes about what I learned

> **Tip:** Press `Shift + Enter` to run a cell!




Let‚Äôs experiment by creating a data visualization using some popular Python packages.

Create a new notebook and name it plotting_penguins.ipynb or something like that.
Next, we need to install the following Python libraries / packages:

pandas - for working with data tables
matplotlib - for creating data visualizations
seaborn - some additional functionality and assistance working with matplotlib


To install these, we will use uv in the terminal:
uv add pandas matplotlib seaborn
Note: we can install multiple packages at once using this syntax.

In the first code cell in the new notebook, let‚Äôs install the necessary packages:


import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


Next, we can import a preloaded dataset from seaborn and preview its data:


# Load a built-in dataset (no files needed!)
penguins = sns.load_dataset('penguins')

# Take a quick look at the data
print("üêß Palmer Penguins Dataset")
print("=" * 50)
print(penguins.head())
print(f"\nTotal penguins: {len(penguins)}")
print(f"Species: {penguins['species'].unique()}")

üêß Palmer Penguins Dataset
==================================================

Total penguins: 344
Species: ['Adelie' 'Chinstrap' 'Gentoo']



Now, let‚Äôs create a pair plot of this data:


# Create visualization in ONE line!
sns.pairplot(penguins, hue='species', palette='husl')

plt.suptitle('üêß Penguin Data Overview', y=1.01, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
plt.show()

C:\Users\F0040RP\Documents\DartLib_RDS\projects\python-setup\.venv\Lib\site-packages\IPython\core\pylabtools.py:170: UserWarning: Glyph 128039 (\N{PENGUIN}) missing from font(s) DejaVu Sans.
  fig.canvas.print_figure(bytes_io, **kw)









Or, we can create a scatterplot with additional customization:

# Create a colorful visualization
sns.set_style("whitegrid")
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))

# Scatter plot: flipper length vs body mass, colored by species
sns.scatterplot(
    data=penguins,
    x='flipper_length_mm',
    y='body_mass_g',
    hue='species',
    size='body_mass_g',
    sizes=(50, 400),
    alpha=0.7,
    palette='Set2'
)

Open Visual Studio Code, which you installed with notebook 01.
Click on File ‚Äì> Open Folder. Navigate to your new project folder and open it.
In the left pane of VSC, click on the Explorer icon (looks like pages or files) and you will see your empty folder there.

title: Create Python Project from Scratch
text:
As noted in the opening slides presentation (html or pdf) ‚ÄúA virtual environment keeps each project‚Äôs packages separate and organized, preventing conflicts and making your code easy to share.‚Äù
We will now use uv to create a virtual environment for our sample project.



Select the Terminal tab at the top of VSC ‚Äì> New Terminal
A new terminal should appear at the bottom.
If you are using a PC, it is recommended you use a Command Prompt terminal instead of Powershell. To open Command, select the + symbol at the far right side of the terminal pane, and select Command Prompt.





In the terminal, you can test to see if VSC can find your Python and uv installations (just as we did in notebook 01) by running the following code:

uv --version
uv python list



Make sure you are in the project root folder, i.e.¬†your terminal should look like something like this (with a path to your project directory shown):

If you are not in the project root directory you can navigate to it by using the cd (change directory) command. Some tips:

to navigate up one directory type cd ..
to navigate up 3 directories type cd ../../..
to navigate from the current working directory into your code folder type cd code.
to navigate down two directories, type something like this: cd code/scripts (assuming the code folder is in your current working directory and a scripts folder is inside of that.

Now, run the following in your project‚Äôs root directory from the terminal:
# This initiaties a new uv environment for your project
uv init
You will see in the Explorer pane on the left side of VSC several new files and folders were created in your project‚Äôs working directory. The above command:

Installed Python if the correct version isn‚Äôt available
Created a pyproject.toml file, where uv will store information about the packages / dependencies used in this project.
Created a .python-version file to store the version of Python used for this project.




Initiating uv may also create a uv.lock file and a '.venv folder if you have already installed some packages. Let‚Äôs test this out by installing a package to our local environment at which point this file and folder will be created:
Run in the terminal:
uv add requests
Certainly, now you should see the following in your project‚Äôs root directory:
-   a `uv.lock` file which may be used by others (or by yourself in a different environment) to reproduce the exact same computing environment for your project.

-   a `.venv` folder where the code for all projects added to the local environment are stored
You can also install / add multiple packages at once:
uv add numpy pandas rich
You can use uv remove to uninstall packages. We really didn‚Äôt need requests. Let‚Äôs uninstall it:
uv remove requests
You can review what packages have been installed in multiple ways. You can open either the pyproject.toml or the uv.lock file. Or you can run the following in the terminal:
uv pip list
You should see something like this:
Package         Version
--------------- -----------
markdown-it-py  4.0.0
mdurl           0.1.2
numpy           2.4.1
pandas          2.3.3
pygments        2.19.2
python-dateutil 2.9.0.post0
pytz            2025.2
rich            14.2.0
six             1.17.0
tzdata          2025.3
*Note: the .toml file and uv pip list return all packages installed including dependencies. For example, when we installed rich, UV also installed the packages rich depends on: markdown-it-py, mdurl, and pygments. In contrast, the uv.lock just lists the actual packages that you, the user, installed:
dependencies = [
    "numpy>=2.4.1",
    "pandas>=2.3.3",
    "rich>=14.2.0",
]
This is because uv.lock serves as instructions for the re-creation of this environment on another computer. If you were to open this project on a different computer, you would run the command uv sync, which would recreate your environment by installing the specific versions of numpy, pandas, and rich you have installed on your machine. When those are installed, their dependencies will be automatically installed as well.
Now, try running this:
pip list
Notice any difference from the results returned by uv pip list? In my case this second command returned many, many more packages? Why? It‚Äôs because the uv command automatically just retrieves the names of packages installed to the local virtual environment, whereas pip is retrieving all packages installed. That is why, under the pip system, you need to activate your virtual environment with .venv/Scripts/activate (Windows) or .venv/bin/activate (Macs) every time you open a project. Fortunately, with uv, we are automatically using the virtual environment whenever we call uv within a project that has one.



One final step: every time we start a new project in VSC we need to configure VSC to use the correct version of Python. We can do this by selecting our Python interpreter:

Open the ‚ÄúShow and Run Command Bars‚Äù (either select from central dropdown project menu at top of screen or by clicking CTRL + SHIFT + P on Windows or CMD + CTRL + SPACE on a Mac)
Search for and select Python: Select Interpreter



Select ‚ÄúPython: Select Interpreter‚Äù from Show and Run Command Bars


Choose the version of Python installed to your local environment. It should look something like this: `Python 3.14.2 (name-of-project) .venv/Scripts/python.exe Recommended‚Äù



Select the version of Python found within your local project environment



Let‚Äôs view which version of Python is being used by this project. Run the following in the terminal:
uv run python --version

title: Create Python Project from Scratch
text:
A markdown file is a text file that allows you to use simple symbols to specify its formatting. This notebook and the 00_setup_slides presentation were both created using markdown.
Some commonly used symbols:
# Header level 1 (note '#' should be the first symbol on the line and followed by a single whitespace)
## Header level 2
### Header level 3
**bold**
*italics*
[filename](link/to/file)   # to create hyperlinks
```
place code blocks between sets of 3 back ticks
```
In the Explorer pane on the left, create a new file using the + File icon and name it README.md (.md is the extension for a markdown file).
Create a skeletal outline of a README file using headers of different levels, bold, italics, links, and code blocks (see the symbol directory above or the Markdown Guide‚Äôs Cheat Sheet for more examples of Markdown syntax). Include the following information:

tentative name of your project
name(s) of author(s) (you!)
Overview section
Data section
Methods section

Save the file.

title: Create Python Project from Scratch
text:
Create a Python script in your code/ folder and name it something like this: greeting.py.

Create a new script either by navigating to the code/ folder, right-clicking it, and selecting New File. Be sure to give the file the .py extension.
OR File ‚Äì> New File and then give your file a name and place it in the code folder.
*Note: using the correct extension is essential so the computer knows how to read it. A .py file is a plain text file containing Python code that can be run with software like VSC or from the command line.*

Type / paste in the following code (modifying it to make it your own) in the Python script:

# Get the user's name
name = input("What's your name? ")

# print(name, "is a beautiful name.")

Save the script (important: when you run a script it will only run the most recently saved version).
Run your script in the terminal using uv:

uv run code/greeting.py

Other options to run this file:

Right-click anywhere within greeting.py (in VSC) and select Run Python ‚Äì> Run Python File in Terminal
You can also run the script by selecting the Play icon button at the top of the editor window where you have greeting.py. Note: with this method, you are NOT using uv to run the script. Therefore, VSC may not know which Python version on your computer to run or it may choose a version that doesn‚Äôt work. If you get an error: choose the version that looks something like this: Python 3.XX.X (sample-project) .\.venv\Scripts\python.exe              Workspace.




add to your Python script:
# Get their favorite color
color = input("What's your favorite color? ")

# Respond based on their color choice
if color.lower() == "blue":
    print(f"Hello, {name}! Blue is a calm and peaceful color. Great choice!")
elif color.lower() == "red":
    print(f"Hello, {name}! Red is bold and energetic. I like it!")
elif color.lower() == "green":
    print(f"Hello, {name}! Green is the color of nature. Very refreshing!")
else:
    print(f"Hello, {name}! {color.title()} is a wonderful color!")



You can only do a few simple things with core Python code. Anything more complex - from data analysis to statistics, working with images and text, etc. - you will need to:

install the package to your local environment using uv (do this once per project)
import the package into any scripts or notebooks that use it (must include in each code script or notebook)

We will create a random compliments generator in a Python script, which requires the use of two packages:

random (which is part of the core Python installation and thus DOES NOT need to be installed, but DOES need to be imported) and
rich (which DOES NEED to be installed AND imported).

To install rich run the following in the terminal:
uv add rich 
You can confirm the installation of this package to your local environment in multiple ways.

Open the pyproject.toml file and you should see it listed among the dependencies.
Open uv.lock and you can see information about the installed rich package.
Review code files for the rich package stored in .venv/Lib/site-packages.
Type uv pip list or uv pip freeze in the command line / terminal.

NOTE: Never manually modify any of the above unless you know what you are doing. These files and folders are manually updated by uv when you run uv commands.
Then paste / type the following into a new Python script called compliment_generator.py.
import random
from rich import print

# List of compliments
compliments = [
    "You're doing an amazing job learning Python! üéâ",  # \U0001F389
    "Your curiosity is inspiring! üåü",                  # \U00002B50
    "You have great potential as a programmer! üíª",
    "Keep up the excellent work! üöÄ",                   # \U0001F680"
    "You're braver than you think for trying something new! üí™"
    "‚ú®"
]

# Get user's name
name = input("What's your name? ")

# Pick a random compliment
chosen_compliment = random.choice(compliments)

# Print with color using rich
print(f"\n[bold cyan]Hey {name}![/bold cyan]")
print(f"[green]{chosen_compliment}[/green]\n")
Note: to acquire these and other emojis:

on a PC press Windows + . or Windows + ;
On a Mac type Command + Control + Space.
On a Linux type Ctrl + . or Ctrl + ;.

Try running this script from the command line using the same procedure introduced in the previous step.

title: Create Python Project from Scratch
text:
Coding notebooks allow a user to create a more interactive, modular code script. These notebooks allow users to mix markdown texts (with human-readable instructions and explanations) with code cells, which can be run one at a time or all at once. They also allow users to view various intermediary results (i.e.¬†data tables or visualizations) right within their notebook.
Jupyter is the most commonly used type of coding notebook for Python.



To use Jupyter first we need to install it using uv. Run the following in the terminal:

uv add jupyter




Right-click in the Explorer sidebar (where your files are)
Click ‚ÄúNew File‚Äù
Name it: my_first_notebook.ipynb

-   The `.ipynb` extension is important!

Press Enter





When the notebook opens, look at the top-right corner
Click ‚ÄúSelect Kernel‚Äù
Choose ‚ÄúPython Environments‚Ä¶‚Äù
Select the one that says .venv or uv





Click in the first cell
Type some Python code
Press Shift + Enter to run the cell
That‚Äôs it! üéâ




A short cheatsheet for working with Jupyter notebooks (or click here for a more extensive cheatsheet:
‚ïî‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïó
‚ïë      JUPYTER NOTEBOOK SHORTCUTS              ‚ïë
‚ï†‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ï£
‚ïë                                              ‚ïë

‚ïë                                              ‚ïë

‚ïë  ‚Ä¢ Click trash icon on left of cell          ‚ïë
‚ïë                                              ‚ïë
‚ïë  SAVE NOTEBOOK:                              ‚ïë

‚ïë                                              ‚ïë
‚ïë  RESTART KERNEL:                             ‚ïë
‚ïë  ‚Ä¢ Click "Restart" icon at top               ‚ïë
‚ïë  ‚Ä¢ Use when things get stuck                 ‚ïë
‚ïë                                              ‚ïë
‚ïö‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïù
Copy and paste these cells into your notebook to practice:


Click the cell, then change it to ‚ÄúMarkdown‚Äù using the dropdown at the top
# üéâ My First Jupyter Notebook

Welcome to my coding adventure! Today I'm learning about Jupyter notebooks.

## What I'll practice:
- Running Python code in cells
- Using **markdown** for notes
- Making calculations
- Creating simple visualizations
---

**Date:** January 2025  
**Mood:** Excited! üöÄ




# Let's do some calculations!
print("üßÆ Quick Math Practice")
print("-" * 30)

my_age = 25  # Change this to your age!
python_age = 2025 - 1991  # Python was created in 1991

print(f"I am {my_age} years old")
print(f"Python is {python_age} years old")
print(f"Python is {python_age - my_age} years older than me!")

üßÆ Quick Math Practice
------------------------------
I am 25 years old
Python is 34 years old
Python is 9 years older than me!





## üí≠ My Observations

The cool thing about notebooks is that I can:
1. Write code
2. See the results immediately
3. Add notes about what I learned

> **Tip:** Press `Shift + Enter` to run a cell!




Let‚Äôs experiment by creating a data visualization using some popular Python packages.

Create a new notebook and name it plotting_penguins.ipynb or something like that.
Next, we need to install the following Python libraries / packages:

pandas - for working with data tables
matplotlib - for creating data visualizations
seaborn - some additional functionality and assistance working with matplotlib


To install these, we will use uv in the terminal:
uv add pandas matplotlib seaborn
Note: we can install multiple packages at once using this syntax.

In the first code cell in the new notebook, let‚Äôs install the necessary packages:


import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


Next, we can import a preloaded dataset from seaborn and preview its data:


# Load a built-in dataset (no files needed!)
penguins = sns.load_dataset('penguins')

# Take a quick look at the data
print("üêß Palmer Penguins Dataset")
print("=" * 50)
print(penguins.head())
print(f"\nTotal penguins: {len(penguins)}")
print(f"Species: {penguins['species'].unique()}")

üêß Palmer Penguins Dataset
==================================================
  species     island  bill_length_mm  bill_depth_mm  flipper_length_mm  \
0  Adelie  Torgersen            39.1           18.7              181.0   
1  Adelie  Torgersen            39.5           17.4              186.0   
2  Adelie  Torgersen            40.3           18.0              195.0   
3  Adelie  Torgersen             NaN            NaN                NaN   
4  Adelie  Torgersen            36.7           19.3              193.0   

   body_mass_g     sex  
0       3750.0    Male  
1       3800.0  Female  
2       3250.0  Female  
3          NaN     NaN  
4       3450.0  Female  

Total penguins: 344
Species: ['Adelie' 'Chinstrap' 'Gentoo']



Now, let‚Äôs create a pair plot of this data:


# Create visualization in ONE line!
sns.pairplot(penguins, hue='species', palette='husl')

plt.suptitle('üêß Penguin Data Overview', y=1.01, fontsize=16, fontweight='bold')
plt.show()

C:\Users\F0040RP\Documents\DartLib_RDS\projects\python-setup\.venv\Lib\site-packages\IPython\core\pylabtools.py:170: UserWarning: Glyph 128039 (\N{PENGUIN}) missing from font(s) DejaVu Sans.
  fig.canvas.print_figure(bytes_io, **kw)









Or, we can create a scatterplot with additional customization:

# Create a colorful visualization
sns.set_style("whitegrid")
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))

# Scatter plot: flipper length vs body mass, colored by species
sns.scatterplot(
    data=penguins,
    x='flipper_length_mm',
    y='body_mass_g',
    hue='species',
    size='body_mass_g',
    sizes=(50, 400),
    alpha=0.7,
    palette='Set2'
)

title: Create Python Project from Scratch
text:
Troubleshooting Section

Problem 1: ‚ÄúSelect Kernel‚Äù Button Missing
Solution:

Make sure you saved the file with .ipynb extension
Close and reopen the file
Install the Jupyter extension: Click Extensions (sidebar) ‚Üí search ‚ÄúJupyter‚Äù ‚Üí Install



Problem 2: Kernel Won‚Äôt Start
Solution:

Open Terminal and run: uv add ipykernel
Reload VS Code: Press Ctrl+Shift+P, type ‚ÄúReload Window‚Äù, press Enter
Try selecting the kernel again



Problem 3: Code Cell Won‚Äôt Run
Symptoms: Nothing happens when you press Shift+Enter
Solution:

Check if kernel is connected (top-right should show Python version)
Click the kernel name and select it again
Restart kernel: Click ‚ÄúRestart‚Äù icon at the top



Problem 4: Matplotlib Charts Don‚Äôt Show
Solution:

Make sure you ran the installation cell (Cell 6)
Add this line before your plotting code:

%matplotlib inline

Restart the kernel and run all cells again

Problem 5: Input() Not Working
Symptoms: Input prompt doesn‚Äôt appear or freezes
Solution:
This is normal in Jupyter! Look for the input box at the TOP of the cell output
Make sure you're running the cell (not just clicking it)
If stuck, click "Interrupt" button at top, then try again
Problem 6: Can‚Äôt Install Packages
Error: ‚Äúuv: command not found‚Äù or similar
Solution:
Use pip instead:

::: {#533a00b0 .cell execution_count=7}
``` {.python .cell-code}
pip install matplotlib
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Note: you may need to restart the kernel to use updated packages.
```
:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}
```
C:\Users\F0040RP\Documents\DartLib_RDS\projects\python-setup\.venv\Scripts\python.exe: No module named pip
```
:::
:::




Problem 5: Input() Not Working
Symptoms: Input prompt doesn‚Äôt appear or freezes
Solution:

This is normal in Jupyter! Look for the input box at the TOP of the cell output
Make sure you‚Äôre running the cell (not just clicking it)
If stuck, click ‚ÄúInterrupt‚Äù button at top, then try again



Problem 6: Markdown Cell Shows Code Instead of Formatted Text
Solution:

Make sure the cell type is set to ‚ÄúMarkdown‚Äù (check dropdown at top)
Run the cell with Shift+Enter to render it
If still showing code, change to Markdown and run again



Problem 7: Notebook is Slow or Unresponsive
Solution:

Restart the kernel: Click ‚ÄúRestart‚Äù icon at top
Clear all outputs: Click ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù menu ‚Üí ‚ÄúClear All Outputs‚Äù
Close other programs to free up memory
Save and reload VS Code
